item.question: You have generated a DSA authentication key on host linux1. In order to log into host linux2 with the new key, what would you need to do?
item.choice: Log into linux2 using the command ssh-key.
Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/id_dsa on linux2.
Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/authorized_keys on linux2.
Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/id_dsa on linux1.
Copy the new authentication key into /etc/ssh/sshd_config on linux2.
item.correct_answer: Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/authorized_keys on linux2.
item.hint: The question is about making public key authentication possible for a user. You may assume $HOME points to the correct user's homedirectory. To enable public key authentication you will need to add the public key from linux1 to the ssh configuration for the user on linux2. If DSA is used the private key is named id_dsa by default, and the public key id_dsa.pub. The latter needs to be copied to the correct file on linux2.

item.question: What is the purpose of the <font face="monospace">export</font> command?
item.choice: To save the history file to a compatible format to be used by other shells.
To run a command in the current shell instead of a child-shell.
To setup environment variables for applications started in the shell.
item.correct_answer: To setup environment variables for applications started in the shell.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Your senior system administrator asks you to do a routinely security audit on a couple of systems. One of the tasks is to get a list of programs that when executed as a normal user will run with root privileges. Which of the following commands would you use to generate such a list?
item.hint: Apparently you are looking for setuid permissions on files, as all choices are concerned with setuid. The program <font face="monospace">locate</font> will not allow you to filter on permissions. The command <font face="monospace">ls</font> might be an option but the <font face="monospace">grep</font> command will only show you directories. So, you are left with two options. Now all you need to know to answer this question correctly, is that for <font face="monospace">find</font> permissions specified after a <font face="monospace">/</font> are logically ORed.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the internet is broken. What would you do first?
item.choice: Get your towel and don't panic.
Ask the user if he/she has tried turning the machine off and on again.
Logon to the user's machine to verify the claim.
Start explaining what the internet is, who invented it, and why it was invented.
item.correct_answer: Logon to the user's machine to verify the claim.
item.hint: Although many sysadmins would love to tell a user to simply turn the machine off and on again this is not considered a professional response. For more information see System Administrators' Code of Ethics. Explaining the user what the internet is might be very interesting for you and the user. However, this will not fix his/her problem.

item.question: Which of the following commands will resolve a hostname to an ip-address? (Choose all correct answers)
item.hint: The question is not which command would you use to resolve a hostname to an ip-address. But which commands do hostname resolving. This means that programs that do accept hostnames and resolve these to ip-addresses to fulfill their task are also correct answers.

item.question: Alice calls to complain that she is not allowed to create a crontab entry. You setup a default deny for crontab usage. Which file would you most likely need to edit to give her access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Your company policy does not allow anything but ssh as a remote login service.
During your monthly security audit you discover that one of your machines provides remote login services
on port 23. What would you do?
item.choice: Deactivate it, you dont need a SMTP server there.
Deactivate it, you should not use <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.
Nothing, this is ok as <font face="monospace">ssh</font> is a safe login service.
Setup a firewall on the machine to block traffic to port 23.
item.correct_answer: Deactivate it, you should not use <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.
item.hint: LPI requires that you know the most common TCP and UDP ports. You can expect questions about portnumbers 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 53, 80, 110, 119, 139, 143, 161, 443, 465, 993, 995. The service <font face="monospace">ssh</font> uses port number 22 which is considered secure. Port 23 is normally used for an insecure login service and should not be used.

item.question: Which switch or switches are used with the <font face="monospace">usermod</font> command to add the group <font face="monospace">user</font> to a user's secondary groups?
item.hint: The default behaviour of <font face="monospace">usermod</font> will be to override the current group memberships. You will need to tell it explicitly to append the group.

item.question: You have just added the above line to your <font face="monospace">syslog.conf</font> file. But, kernel messages are not being sent to the file <font face="monospace">/var/log/kernel.info</font>. What is most likely the problem?
item.choice: You made a syntax error in the file <font face="monospace">syslog.conf</font>
You should have changed the file <font face="monospace">rsyslog.conf</font>
You forgot to restart the syslog daemon
You made a mistake. The facility <font face="monospace">kern</font> should be <font face="monospace">kernel</font>.
item.correct_answer: You forgot to restart the syslog daemon
item.hint: Most daemons do not automatically detect configuration changes. Usually you will use an init-script to have the daemon reload its configuration file or restart.

item.question: In which of the following configuration files can you connect hostnames to ip-addresses?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands creates new log files and moves old ones?
item.hint: The method of moving old log files and possibly compressing them is called log rotation.

item.question: You attached a scsi-device to your system and want to check if the kernel detects the device. Which commandline is BEST to use to see which scsi-devices are connected?
item.hint: The question is about the KERNEL detecting the device and not UDEV. Therefore, the <font face="monospace">/dev</font> directory can be disregarded. The kernel uses a special filesystem to display system information. This filesystem is not located on disk but maintained in memory. However, you can access the contents as if it were normal files and directories on a disk.

item.question: What is the configuration file for the syslog daemon? Give both the path and the filename.
item.hint: There are multiple questions about syslog. Especially the multiple choice questions can come in handy as they may provide you with the exact answer to this question.

item.question: If you want to execute a script called <font face="monospace">findguru</font> and want to disable the variable <font face="monospace">GURU</font> only for the current execution of the script, which of the following commandlines is correct?
item.hint: To setup the environment for a program you use the command <font face="monospace">env</font>.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. When the user starts a non-login shell what will be the value of the variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: All mentioned files in the exhibit are correct. You will need to know which files are read in which order when the user starts a non-login shell.

item.question: What file is used as configuration file for <font face="monospace">sudo</font>? (provide the absolute filename)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You are the system administrator for a consulting firm where several people use Linux as their desktop operating system. One of your users has installed a commercial publishing program that works under X on a variety of UNIX and Linux platforms. The user made a series of configuration changes regarding the initial window size, location and color. Now, he is having difficulty undoing these changes and is asking for your help. Which of the following files contains most likely the configurations changes?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
A user working in Cameroon calls and asks you if there is a way to set the time to her localtime on the server running in Amsterdam.
Which of the following programs would you advice her?
item.hint: The question is about providing the user a tool that allows her to select and set the correct timezone for her login account.

item.question: Concerning the exit value of a command, which of the following is true?
item.choice: You can't test for normal execution by checking the exit value.
When the command failed execution the exit value will be 0.
When the command executed succesfully the exit value will be 0.
An exit value other than 0 will result in the shell being terminated.
item.correct_answer: When the command executed succesfully the exit value will be 0.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The mail transfer agent <font face="monospace">postfix</font> is used on your local system. Which files allow you to redirect e-mail sent to <font face="monospace">guru0</font> to a different e-mail address?
item.hint: An alias is usually used to connect an email address for a non-existing user to an existing user. This user does not have to be a user on the same system. To allow a user to manage his or her own e-mail redirection each user can add a hidden file to forward his or her e-mail to another e-mail address.

item.question: You want syslog to sent all kernel messages with priority critical to all terminal-screens. Which of the following syslog configuration entries would you use?
item.hint: Most programs use the asterisk (<font face="monospace">*</font>) to specify all.

item.question: Take a close look at the above exhibit from <font face="monospace">/etc/crontab</font>. Which of the following statements is true?
item.choice: The script file <font face="monospace">/etc/cron.report</font> is run on the 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 9th day in january
The contents of the <font face="monospace">/etc/cron.report</font> directory are run in january, march, june, and september.
The script file <font face="monospace">/etc/cron.report</font> is run in january, march, june, and september on monday.
During some parts of the year <font face="monospace">/etc/cron.special</font> is run one hour after <font face="monospace">/etc/cron.weekly</font>.
item.correct_answer: The contents of the <font face="monospace">/etc/cron.report</font> directory are run in january, march, june, and september.
item.hint: The format for a system crontab entry is: <font face="monospace">minute hour day_of_month month day_of_week user command</font>

item.question: You want to convert the text-file <font face="monospace">guru.txt</font> to postscript to have it printed out later on. Which of the following commandlines would you use to accomplish this?
item.hint: Note that the question mentions you will be printing later on. Therefore, the correct answer only converts the file and does not print it as well.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to determine the MAC address of a network card installed in your laptop?
item.hint: Two of the commands are non-existing. The others both provide MAC address information. However, only one of them will show you which MAC address is associated with a specific network card.

item.question: Which of the following commandlines will stop all running processes with the name <font face="monospace">catchme</font>? (Select two)
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">ps</font> will show a header which will not contain valid input for the <font face="monospace">kill</font> command. Also, be sure to pick TWO answers. Any other amount is incorrect.

item.question: Which command generated the output in above exhibit?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Your logfiles are getting very large and you decide to exclude all log messages of a given logging facility. Which priority should you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want the system with hostname <font face="monospace">atc</font> to be able to use your local system to display a graphical application. Which of the following commands would allow ONLY <font face="monospace">atc</font> access to your local Xorg server?
item.hint: With xhost you can grant or deny access for a certain host. With xhost access is added or subtracted.

item.question: Which command is used to view the queue for the <font face="monospace">at</font>-command?
item.hint: If not stated explicitly assume only the command name is required and not the path as well.

item.question: Which of the following tools is best to copy a file over a network in a secure manner?
item.hint: We are looking for a “secure copy” mechanism.

item.question:
On a system with a single network interface you are asked to make sure remotely logged in users are disconnected.
Which command would you use?
item.hint: The question does not tell you if running processes may be stopped as well. As you are assumed to be a good sysadmin you should pick the option that will minimize system disruption. Therefore, you should try to only disconnect the users and not bring down anything that can be kept running. To make it clear, shutting down is not considered a viable option nor switching to single user mode. Asking users politely to go away or killing them will probably not work.

item.question: Which entry in <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> is used to specify the location of the fonts for the X window system?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following can you use to disable the system bell sound?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following shell variables specifies the Xorg server and screen that will be used by a graphical application?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You are using an application that you want to appear on the screen of another machine. What environment variable would you have to set or edit to achieve this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The __________ file maps TCP and UDP ports to service names.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: To let your NTP service synchronize with an external source you would modify the file?
item.hint: Most programs that use a configuration file under <font face="monospace">/etc</font> create a new directory usually naming it after the program. However, <font face="monospace">ntp</font> does not and places its configuration file directly under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>.

item.question: In the passwd file, you changed <font face="monospace">/bin/bash</font> to <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font> for user bob. What best describes the effect on bob's account?
item.choice: When bob logs in on a terminal screen he will immediately logout.
Bob will be asked to provide a new shell to use
item.correct_answer: When bob logs in on a terminal screen he will immediately logout.
item.hint: The default shell for a specific user is specified in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. The default shell specification should point to an executable that is started by a terminal when it needs to run a shell. The program <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font> will do nothing but exit with an exit code indicating a failure.

item.question: The network administrator provided you with a network range 192.168.0.32/26. You need two addresses for a router and DNS server. How many addresses are left for other hosts in the network?
item.hint: Within any network range the address with the host part all zero's or one's cannot be assigned to a network interface in the network. This means that two addresses in the range can not be used. The question states that two valid ip addresses are assigned to the router and a nameserver. Therefore, you will need to subtract 4 from the total amount of addresses in the range.

item.question: You need to change the toner in a printer. Which of the following utilities allows you to stop the printserver from sending new printjobs to the printer but keeps accepting new printjobs from clients?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Users complain they cannot login to a server. However, you have no problem remote logging in as root. What best explains this situation?
item.choice: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> is not present.
The presence of the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nologin</font>.
The set-uid bit on <font face="monospace">/bin/login</font> is missing.
item.correct_answer: The presence of the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nologin</font>.
item.hint: The question does not state anything about remote logins. Therefore, any options regarding remote logins can be discarded. You are now still left with multiple options. From there you should select the most probable reason for the stated problem.

item.question: Which utility can be used to restrict access to services managed by <font face="monospace">inetd</font>?
item.hint: The restriction mentioned in the question is network restriction through the TCP wrapper library. The service <font face="monospace">inetd</font> does not have support for TCP wrapper builtin. To enable access restriction using the TCP wrapper library <font face="monospace">inetd</font> can use a separate program to perform the check on behalf of <font face="monospace">inetd</font>.

item.question: You downloaded a script and notice that the first line starts with <font face="monospace">#!</font>. What is the purpose of this line?
item.choice: The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will replace the script
The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will be executed to interpret the script.
The <font face="monospace">#!</font> sign tells the shell where to start executing the script
The line will be ignored as it starts with <font face="monospace">#</font>
item.correct_answer: The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will be executed to interpret the script.
item.hint: The <font face="monospace">#!</font> is used by the kernel to determine which interpreter must be started to actually read and execute the script.

item.question: Which of the following are window managers? Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: Remember a window manager is not the same as a desktop manager. Although sometimes they are combined.

item.question: The __________ command prints a list of e-mail that is currently in the queue waiting for delivery.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to make sure all users, when they login, get access to a new program in <font face="monospace">/opt/bin</font> (not currently in their PATH). To ensure this you would put the command in above exhibit in what file? (provide full pathname)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the above syslog priorities.
Which represents the highest priority?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Some priorities have multiple names. Usually a short abbreviated version and a long version.

item.question: The _________ file configures the <font face="monospace">syslogd</font> logging daemon.
item.hint: As the question does not mention anything about providing a pathname you may assume it is optional.

item.question: Which <font face="monospace">syslog</font> facility is used by the <font face="monospace">cron</font> daemon?
item.hint: Sometimes the facility matches the name of the daemon.

item.question: The _________ command is used to send ECHO_REQUEST packets.
item.hint: An ECHO_REQUEST is an ICMP message whose data is expected back to the sender in a ECHO_REPLY packet. It is used mostly to check if the remote host is reachable over a network.

item.question: Considering a Debian linux system. What are the default permissions for the <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> file?
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> must be readable by everyone.

item.question: Your senior sysadmin created the script show above to create a daily backup of the directory <font face="monospace">/data</font> on multiple servers and sent each backup to the backupserver. However, you notice that sometimes backups are missing. To check if the backup succeeded you want to extend above script. Which of the following would sent an email showing the status of the backup and the date the backup was made.
item.hint: Using <font face="monospace">&&</font> and/or <font face="monospace">||</font> will only check the exit value of the previous command. Also note the usage of double and single quotes.

item.question: Which configuration file should be modified to change the action for the <font face="monospace">ctrl-alt-delete</font> key combination to something other than reboot?
item.hint: Two choices are bogus and you should be able to eliminate these rather quickly. You will be left with two options that both can be used to modify the system behavior when pression the <font face="monospace">ctrl-alt-delete</font> key combination. Fortunately, the question states you want to change the action to something other than rebooting. Changing the action using the online kernel parameter will not allow you to do anything other than reboot.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the monitor does not work. You remember adding an extra network-card to her machine yesterday and did not test the new setup because of an urgent meeting. You have a feeling that the network card might be conflicting with the video-card. Which file would you check to see if there are any hardware address conflicts?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: From the following list of names select TWO that provide print-services on a linux system.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Your department decided to change the Gnome Display Manager's greeting. What configuration file should you edit?
item.hint: This is a nasty question. The default location for configuration files is under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>. However, this does not apply for the Gnome display manager. So you are left with either <font face="monospace">/opt</font> or <font face="monospace">/usr</font> as possible choices. As you know that <font face="monospace">/opt</font> is rarely used under Linux your best bet would be to go for <font face="monospace">/usr</font>.

item.question: Consider the above command. What does the argument <font face="monospace">-s</font> do?
item.choice: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Show the account settings for <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Nothing, as <font face="monospace">useradd</font> does not know about an option <font face="monospace">-s</font>
item.correct_answer: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
item.hint: Most programs try to make the options as intuitive as possible. They usually are the first letter of the spelled out option name.

item.question: Which of the following files are used by a linux system for name to ip-address translations? (Select TWO answers.)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command allows you to make a shell variable visible to subshells?
item.hint: If you want the shell to replace a variable with its contents you should precede it with a dollar sign ($). If you want to manipulate a variable you should only specify its name (without the <font face="monospace">$</font>). The command <font face="monospace">set</font> is used to configure the shell. Executing <font face="monospace">set</font> without arguments will print all defined variables. The command <font face="monospace">env</font> can be used to run a program in a modified environment. Running <font face="monospace">env</font> without any arguments will show the current environment. The command <font face="monospace">export</font> is a shell builtin to add variables for automatic inclusion to the enviroment of subsequently executed commands.

item.question: You need to convert a textfile using the WINDOWS-1253 character encoding to UTF-8. Which of the following commands allows you to do this?
item.hint: You might be in doubt about <font face="monospace">convert</font>. However, the tool <font face="monospace">convert</font> is used to convert between image formats and not character encoding schemes.
